supahnickie.caffeine

Class CaffeineConnection

  • java.lang.Object
    • supahnickie.caffeine.CaffeineConnection

  • public final class CaffeineConnection
extends java.lang.Object
    CaffeineConnection is the connection handler and can also be used to run direct SQL queries/updates. All configuration must be properly set before any queries can be run.
    See Also:
    README containing examples, including initialization

    • Method Detail

      • listDatabases

        public static final java.util.Set<java.lang.String> listDatabases()
        Since multiple databases can be configured by CaffeineORM, this function will remind you which ones are available for use.
        Returns:
        Set of database aliases that have been configured and are ready to use.

      • raiseNoQuerySetException

        public static final void raiseNoQuerySetException()
                                           throws java.lang.Exception
        Invoked when a query is run without the application having set the query class yet. See CaffeineObject.setQueryClass(Class)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • useDatabase

        public static final void useDatabase(java.lang.String name)
                              throws java.lang.Exception
        Before any queries can be run, CaffeineORM must be told what database to use. At least one database alias and set of credentials must be added using the addDatabaseConnection() function before this function can be used.
        Parameters:
        name - User-defined alias for the database to use. Credentials are fetched and connections are then ready to be made.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • addDatabaseConnection

        public static final void addDatabaseConnection(java.lang.String name,
                                               java.lang.String driver,
                                               java.lang.String url,
                                               java.lang.String username,
                                               java.lang.String password,
                                               java.lang.Integer concurrency)
        Before any queries can be run, CaffeineORM must be told what database to use and how to connect to it. At least one database alias and set of credentials must be added using this function, then you may use the useDatabase() function to tell CaffeineORM which one to use.
        Parameters:
        name - Alias for the database name you would like to use when switching between database connections
        driver - The JDBC driver needed to talk to your database. Example - "org.postgresql.Driver"
        url - The url to connect to the database
        username - Username string
        password - Password string
        concurrency - Number of open connections to maintain to database

      • destroyConnectionPools

        public static final void destroyConnectionPools()
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Closes all connections for all databases.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • destroyConnectionPool

        public static final void destroyConnectionPool(java.lang.String dbName)
                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Closes all connections for a specific database.
        Parameters:
        dbName - User-assigned alias for the database that should have the connection pool destroyed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • rawUpdate

        public static final void rawUpdate(java.lang.String sql)
                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Function to perform a raw SQL update to the database. The string will be interpreted literally. This function should only be used for INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE actions.
        Parameters:
        sql - Raw SQL to execute
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        README containing examples

      • rawUpdate

        public static final void rawUpdate(java.lang.String sql,
                                   java.util.List<java.lang.Object> args)
                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Function to perform a raw SQL update to the database. This version of the function signature expects either JDBC style placeholders (?) or bind variables ($1, $2) to be used. This function should only be used for INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE actions.
        Parameters:
        sql - Raw SQL to execute (with placeholders)
        args - A list of Objects to be inserted into the placeholders
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        README containing examples

      • rawUpdate

        public static final void rawUpdate(java.lang.String sql,
                                   java.lang.Object... args)
                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Function to perform a raw SQL update to the database. This version of the function signature expects either JDBC style placeholders (?) or bind variables ($1, $2) to be used. This function should only be used for INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE actions.
        Parameters:
        sql - Raw SQL to execute (with placeholders)
        args - Varargs of type Object to be inserted into the placeholders
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        README containing examples

      • rawQuery

        public static final java.util.List<java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>> rawQuery(java.lang.String sql)
                                                                                           throws java.lang.Exception
        Function to perform a raw SQL query of the database. All the rawQuery functions are not required to have the query class set because they return a raw List of HashMaps containing the attributes in a String, Object pairing. This function is particularly useful when doing more complex SQL queries (such as returning attributes from two or more tables or aggregate functions).
        Parameters:
        sql - Raw SQL to execute
        Returns:
        List of records not tied to a specific model, with keys being columns and values being data fields returned from the query.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        README containing examples

      • rawQuery

        public static final java.util.List<java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>> rawQuery(java.lang.String sql,
                                                                                                  java.util.List<java.lang.Object> args)
                                                                                           throws java.lang.Exception
        Function to perform a raw SQL query of the database. All the rawQuery functions are not required to have the query class set because they return a raw List of HashMaps containing the attributes in a String, Object pairing. This function is particularly useful when doing more complex SQL queries (such as returning attributes from two or more tables or aggregate functions). This version of the function signature expects either JDBC style placeholders (?) or bind variables ($1, $2) to be used.
        Parameters:
        sql - Raw SQL to execute (with placeholders)
        args - A list of Objects to be inserted into the placeholders
        Returns:
        List of records not tied to a specific model, with keys being columns and values being data fields returned from the query.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        README containing examples

      • rawQuery

        public static final java.util.List<java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>> rawQuery(java.lang.String sql,
                                                                                                  java.lang.Object... args)
                                                                                           throws java.lang.Exception
        Function to perform a raw SQL query of the database. All the rawQuery functions are not required to have the query class set because they return a raw List of HashMaps containing the attributes in a String, Object pairing. This function is particularly useful when doing more complex SQL queries (such as returning attributes from two or more tables or aggregate functions). This version of the function signature expects either JDBC style placeholders (?) or bind variables ($1, $2) to be used.
        Parameters:
        sql - Raw SQL to execute (with placeholders)
        args - Varargs of type Object to be inserted into the placeholders
        Returns:
        List of records not tied to a specific model, with keys being columns and values being data fields returned from the query.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        README containing examples

      • objectQuery

        public static final java.util.List<CaffeineObject> objectQuery(java.lang.String sql)
                                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Function to perform a raw SQL query of the database that is coerced into a CaffeineObject abstract type. The query class must be set before any of the objectQuery methods are used so the runner knows how to assign the data returned by the SQL into the CaffeineObject. See CaffeineObject.setQueryClass(Class)
        Parameters:
        sql - Raw SQL to execute
        Returns:
        List of CaffeineObjects populated with data from the database. The return is always a list, even when there is only one record.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        README containing examples

      • objectQuery

        public static final java.util.List<CaffeineObject> objectQuery(java.lang.String sql,
                                                               java.util.List<java.lang.Object> args)
                                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Function to perform a raw SQL query of the database that is coerced into a CaffeineObject abstract type. The query class must be set before any of the objectQuery methods are used so the runner knows how to assign the data returned by the SQL into the CaffeineObject. This version of the function signature expects either JDBC style placeholders (?) or bind variables ($1, $2) to be used. See CaffeineObject.setQueryClass(Class)
        Parameters:
        sql - Raw SQL to execute (with placeholders)
        args - A list of Objects to be inserted into the placeholders
        Returns:
        List of CaffeineObjects populated with data from the database. The return is always a list, even when there is only one record.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        README containing examples

      • objectQuery

        public static final java.util.List<CaffeineObject> objectQuery(java.lang.String sql,
                                                               java.lang.Object... args)
                                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Function to perform a raw SQL query of the database that is coerced into a CaffeineObject abstract type. The query class must be set before any of the objectQuery methods are used so the runner knows how to assign the data returned by the SQL into the CaffeineObject. This version of the function signature expects either JDBC style placeholders (?) or bind variables ($1, $2) to be used. See CaffeineObject.setQueryClass(Class)
        Parameters:
        sql - Raw SQL to execute (with placeholders)
        args - Varargs of type Object to be inserted into the placeholders
        Returns:
        List of CaffeineObjects populated with data from the database. The return is always a list, even when there is only one record.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        README containing examples

      • query

        public static final java.util.List<CaffeineObject> query(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> args)
                                                  throws java.lang.Exception
        Function to perform an ActiveRecord-like query of the database, using the keys in the args hash as columns and the values as the where conditions for which to look up records by. The query class must be set before any of the objectQuery methods are used so the runner knows how to assign the data returned by the SQL into the CaffeineObject. See CaffeineObject.setQueryClass(Class)
        Parameters:
        args - Map of arguments with the keys being column names and the values being limiting conditions (i.e. where {KEY} = {VALUE})
        Returns:
        List of CaffeineObjects populated with data from the database. The return is always a list, even when there is only one record.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        README containing examples
